original_title: Sri Lanka cabinet okays payments for govt employees despite no pay leave to contest LG polls
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s cabinet has approved payments for 48 days for those who went on no pay leave in their government jobs to run for local government election earlier scheduled for March 9, Cabinet Spokesman said.
The election, however, was not held as scheduled on March 9.

The move comes amid street protests demanding to hold local polls as soon as possible with thousands of government employees who had taken leave to contest in the Local Government (LG) polls were not allowed to join their former jobs officially amid delay to hold the polls.
The Election Commission had to postpone the polls due to lack of funding by the government.

The Election Commission has yet to announce the LG poll date for the third time after the March 9 election was postponed to April 25. However, Election Commission officials have said the April 25 schedule is unlikely because no ballot paper has been printed and postal voting has not been conducted yet.
Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said nearly 3,000 government employees have gone on no pay  leave to contest in the upcoming LG polls in line with the Establishment Code.

“Since the Local Government elections have been postponed for now, these officials are economically inconvenienced as their unpaid leave also has been extended,” Gunawardena told a weekly Cabinet media briefing on Tuesday (04).

The cabinet on the request of Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena as the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government has approved to pay basic salaries of the officials who are on no pay leave from March 9 to April 25, Gunawardena said. (Colombo/April04/2023)
